===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|あさ|ぬの|yomi=k}}
Compound of {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=あさぬの}} elements {{compound|lang=ja|sort=あさぬの|麻|tr1=asa|t1=hemp, ramie|布|tr2=nuno|t2=woven cloth other than silk}}<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|あさぬの|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|あさぬの}}

# [[cloth]] woven of [[hemp]] or [[ramie]], similar to [[linen]]

=====Usage notes=====
This appears to be the most common term for [[hempen]] [[cloth]].

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|あさ|ふ|yomi=y}}
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=あさふ|麻|tr1=asa|t1=hemp, ramie|布|tr2=fu|t2=woven cloth}}<ref name="KDJ"/>. This uses the [[音読み|''on'yomi'']] of ''fu'' for {{ja-l|布}}, deriving from {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=あさふ}} {{m|ltc|布|tr=pu<sup>H</sup>}}; compare modern {{etyl|cmn|-}} reading ''bù''.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=y|あさふ}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|あさふ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=あさふ|obsolete}} [[cloth]] woven of [[hemp]] or [[ramie]], similar to [[linen]]

=====Usage notes=====
This term appears to be used in modern Japanese. It is not included in the ''Shinmeikai'' monolingual Japanese dictionary<ref name="SMK5">{{R:Shinmeikai5}}</ref>, nor in the ''Daijirin'' monolingual Japanese dictionary.<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

===Etymology 3===
{{ja-kanjitab|あざ|ぶ|yomi=irreg}}
Most likely a compound of {{etyl|ojp|-}} elements {{compound|lang=ja|sort=あさふ|麻|tr1=asa|t1=hemp, ramie|生|tr2=fu|t2=place where things grow}}, given that the Azabu area was known in ancient times as a place for growing hemp or ramie<ref name="KDJ"/>.

This ''fu'' element also appears in terms such as {{m|ja|粟生|tr=awafu||a field for growing millet}}<ref name="KDJ"/><ref name="DJR"/> and {{m|ja|豆生}}, {{m|ja|豆田|tr=mamefu||a field for growing beans}}<ref name="KDJ"/>. The use of {{ja-l|布}} to spell the ''fu'' portion would be an example of [[ateji]], probably influenced by the way that hemp is used to make cloth ({{ja-l|布}}).

The reasons for the shift in pronunciation from ''asafu'' to ''azabu'' remain unclear.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=irr|あざぶ}}

====Proper noun====
{{ja-pos|proper|あざぶ}}

# [[w:Azabu, Tokyo|Azabu]], an area in [[w:Minato, Tokyo|Minato ward, Tokyo]]

====Adjective====
{{ja-adj|infl=na|あざぶ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=あざぶ|dated}} of unknown [[intent]]
#: This usage developed from the idiom. See '''Idioms''' below for details.
#* {{lang|ja|何事も'''麻布'''にて、様々どうらくをなし給ふ}}<ref>'''1763''': [[w:Hiraga Gennai|Hiraga Gennai]], ''Nenashigusa'' (a ''[[w:Dangibon|dangibon]]'')</ref>
#*: {{lang|ja|なにごとも'''あざぶ'''にて、さまざまどうらくをなしたまふ}}
#*: Nanigoto mo '''azabu''' ni te, samazama dōraku o nashitamau...
#*:: Everything of [his] '''real intentions is unknown''', and [he] amuses himself with various diversions...

=====Idioms=====
* {{ja-r|麻布で気が知れぬ|あざぶ で き が しれぬ}}: “you can't figure out the feeling [intent] in Azabu” → based on a [[pun]] on the phrase “you can't figure out [identify] the trees in Azabu”, substituting {{m|ja|気|tr=ki||sense, intent, feeling}} for {{m|ja|木|tr=ki||tree}}, appearing in print in 1763. This derives from the way that the Azabu area includes the [[w:Roppongi, Minato, Tokyo|Roppongi]] neighborhood. Although Roppongi is spelled as {{m|ja|六本木||six trees}}, there have not been any trees in the area that would match this description for quite some time.<ref name="KDJ"/><ref name="DJR"/>

===Etymology 4===
{{ja-kanjitab|ま|ふ|yomi=on}}
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=まふ}} compound {{m|zh|麻布|tr=mæ pu<sup>H</sup>}}. Compare modern {{etyl|cmn|-}} reading ''mábù''.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=o|まふ|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|まふ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=まふ|rare}} [[cloth]] woven of [[hemp]] or [[ramie]], similar to [[linen]]

=====Usage notes=====
This term appears to be less commonly used. It is not included in the ''Shinmeikai'' monolingual Japanese dictionary.<ref name="SMK5">{{R:Shinmeikai5}}</ref>
